Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: Leadership needs a prompt reply to confirm details for an external partner.
Expectation2: Coordinate with other air traffic controllers to ensure smooth traffic flow
Situation2: Thunderstorm cells force multiple flights to reroute, increasing handoffs between sectors.
Story: The storm radar glowed red and yellow, and my headset crackled with voices—Delta 452 requesting a new heading, United 309 needing a lower altitude. My focus tunneled in on the radar, hands moving almost automatically as I coordinated with the next sector, trying to keep the airspace safe. In the corner of my eye, my work phone buzzed again. The subject line flashed: “URGENT: Partner Confirmation Needed.” Leadership was waiting for my reply, and I knew the external partner’s schedule depended on it. I could almost feel my manager’s expectation pressing on me—quick, professional communication, always responsive. But every second I spent glancing at my inbox was a second I wasn’t watching the shifting storm cells or listening for a pilot’s call. My mind raced, torn between the immediate, life-or-death demands of the airspace and the professional responsibility to my team. The pressure built in my chest, and I stared at the blinking cursor in my email, headset still alive with the voices of pilots depending on me.
